workItem.title: Software Engineer
description: I'm currently working as a software engineer at Arity! It's been an absolutely fantastic experience so far and I look forward to continuing to work with them.

My work is on the Shared Mobility, Vehicle Insights team, which delivers APIs and implements front-end mock-ups. My team's customers are typically data-driven ride-sharing companies, whom we provide with insight on vehicle conditions and driver information.
Our tech stack is React.js for the front-end, Sprint Boot Kotlin for the back-end and a mix of Postgres and Cassandra for our databases.

workItem.title: Americas IT Intern
description: I had an amazing experience as an intern at Allegion. I worked as full-stack developer, utilizing a .NET API back-end and Angular front-end.

The major project I worked on as a team developer was the Customer Order Status Project, which required developing back-end controllers to sort users by region and/or brand. Additionally, I developed a controller that, given an order number, returned tracking info and order details.

On the front-end side, I implemented complex mock-ups and filtered back-end results based on the controllers I made. I also strongly believe in a mobile-first dev approach, so I converted the existing Leads Passing app to be response.

workItem.title: Engineering Intern
description: My first internship as an engineer was a rewarding experience. It was the first time I encountered HTML, CSS and Javascript, and through that, all my future projects and jobs. I'm deeply grateful for the time my co-workers invested in training me. While I was technically an employee of Integris engineering, I worked from the Mossville Caterpillar plant.

While I created a few small applications using a Flask server, my main project that summer was converting legacy Fortran code to a modern Flask app. The project was challenging and presented unique difficulties!

workItem.title: State Intern
description: My very first job (which worked out to be about $2/hour), I worked as an intern for my local state senator, Chuck Weaver. It was an amazing experience that allowed me to connect strongly with the Peoria, Illinois community.
My day-to-day responsibilities involved aiding and helping constituents during the 2016-2017 Illinois budget crisis, directing them to what state resources were available.

While I respect and appreciate Senator Weaver and his team deeply, I do not necessarily agree or disagree with his policies, as I was most motivated as a 17/18 year old in being involved with local government.

funItem.title: Project Lead and Co-Founder
description: Togther with my friends Brian Wilens and Ben Thayer, I founded Open-Source at Illinois, a Mozilla-sponsored club that promoted open-source principles and projects at UIUC. The summer of 2019, I wrote the club's initial website, a MEAN app that utilized Auth0 Github verification

During the school year, I acted as project manager, directing freshmen and sophomores in a variety of projects and open-source contributions. After COVID-19 hit the US, I worked with my team to transition to an completely online community, which is still alive and thriving on Discord.

funItem.title: Research Assistant
description: In my sophomore and junior year, I was involved with Alli Nilles' research into self-assembly and aggregate robotics. Utilizing weasel bots to simulate “dumb” movement, the team designed robots to mechanically form complex shapes (e.g., triangle, square, etc.) without human input
My project was to simulate and model the collision of these robots in a graphical simulator, which I accomplished using the open source PyGame graphical interface

funItem.title: Eagle Scout
description: One of the fundamental building blocks of my childhood, I was regularly involved with Scouts starting from the age of 6 till 15. I have so many fond memories of kayaking, hiking, and swimming every summer. Along the way to getting my Eagle, I discovered a now lifelong interest in personal finance and physical fitness!

My Eagle Scout project was a book drive, which intersected my lifelong love with reading and the lack of funding for library materials in Peoria, Illinois's school district 150. Working with a team of friends and family, we were able to collect approximately a 1000 books that were donated to the Franklin Primary school.
